rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:1
rsbNotes.text:
1 prisoner. Paul knows that he belongs to Christ, and if he is in prison it is by Christ’s permission (Phil. 1:7).

in your house. The early Christians met in believers’ homes (1 Cor. 16:19; Col. 4:15).

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:6
rsbNotes.text: 6 may become effective. Paul is going to suggest a good work that will call on Philemon’s generosity in an important and visible way.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:7
rsbNotes.text: 7 hearts. The word translated “hearts” is used also in vv. 12 and 20. It emphasizes the emotions more than the usual Greek word for “heart.”

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:9
rsbNotes.text: 9 an old man. Paul appeals for mercy by describing himself as old and in prison. He does this “for love’s sake,” not for his own sake.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:10
rsbNotes.text: 10 my child, Onesimus. Onesimus is Paul’s spiritual son because he was converted through Paul’s ministry.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:11
rsbNotes.text: 11 useless . . . useful. Paul makes a play on words—Onesimus’s name means “useful” or “beneficial” (text note). The pun softens the effect on Philemon of having to hear about someone who had injured him. Onesimus had run away and had probably been stealing (v. 18).

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:14
rsbNotes.text: 14 of your own free will. In his letters Paul appeals more than once to the principle that a free and voluntary action is of more value than one that is compulsory (1 Cor. 9:16, 17; 2 Cor. 9:7).

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:16
rsbNotes.text: 16 more than a slave. Paul seems to be asking Philemon to set Onesimus free. It is implied that the Christians’ common freedom in Christ is incompatible with the state of slavery, marked as it is by compulsion (v. 14 note), not to mention chains (v. 10, 13, 14; see 1 Pet. 2:18 note).

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:17
rsbNotes.text: 17 as you would receive me. Paul is willing to throw his friendship with Philemon into the balance to make sure that Philemon will not refuse his request for Onesimus. Paul’s offer to pay Onesimus’s debts (v. 18) is real, but secondary by comparison.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:19
rsbNotes.text: 19 even your own self. This means that Philemon, like Onesimus, owed his Christian faith to the ministry of Paul.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:22
rsbNotes.text: 22 a guest room. Paul anticipates being released, which apparently happened. Whether he reached Colosse is not known.
